guide.introduction:
I just want to get the major "maker beware" statement out of the way first. By it's nature, this is a one-of-a-kind project. It's built around a very specific item: a somewhat uncommon Minolta 35mm camera lens from the late-70's/early-80's.

Though I have shared the 3-D printer (STL) files here, they will not necessarily work with another lens -- you'll have to figure out how to modify them (or design your own from scratch). Also, please bear in mind that not all lenses are well suited to such a project. Newer auto-focus lens designs and zoom lenses (with floating elements) are right out unless you have extensive experience hacking such designs.

Also, please do not waste a lot of money buying lenses in good condition which may or may not work. Try to find "junk" lenses at camera shows or garage sales -- don't spend more than $10. The lens I used here cost me $5 because the focusing mechanism was damaged beyond repair.

The primary reason I'm writing this project up is to give you some example ideas for a similar project of your own, and as a starting point for your own mechatronic eye design.

Tools
  • 1/8" drill bit
  • 1/16" drill bit
  • 3-D printer
  • Electric drill or drill press
  • Sugru

lines.text: When generating the G-code, I -strongly- suggest you use a "raft"  to help prevent warping. Once the pieces are printed and cooled, you'll have to sand the raft off with a belt sander to ensure the mating faces are flat.

guide.summary:
This is a project I made for Halloween 2011. I call it the "Mechatronic Eye". It's an accessory that makes any costume into a "cyborg" costume.

Cyborg Abe Lincoln? You bet!
Cyborg Fairy Princess? Why not?
Cyborg Harry Potter? If you must...
guide.time_required: 4-6 hours, not including PCB fabrication time
